block.p: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $200 million medium-term notes due in 1998 through CS First Boston Corp. The notes, which are callable in a year, carry an interest rate of 7.84 percent and are priced at par. Also through CS First Boston, Fannie Mae is selling $100 million in medium-term notes due in 2000. Callable in three years, the notes carry an interest rate of 7.89 percent and are priced at par.

Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $200 million medium-term notes due in 1998 through CS First Boston Corp. The notes, which are callable in a year, carry an interest rate of 7.84 percent and are priced at par. Also through CS First Boston, Fannie Mae is selling $100 million in medium-term notes due in 2000. Callable in three years, the notes carry an interest rate of 7.89 percent and are priced at par.

* Federal National Mortgage Association is selling $100 million in medium-term notes due in 1997 through Fuji Securities Inc. The notes, which are callable in six months, carry an interest rate of 7.72 percent and are priced at par.

* Massachusetts Health and Educational Facilities Authority is selling $31.1 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 6.875 percent for an issue due in 2015 and 6.75 percent in 2010. For short-maturity serial bonds, yields range from 5.35 percent in 1996 to 6.35 percent in 2005. The bonds are rated A- by Standard & Poor's Corp.

* Norwest Financial Inc., Des Moines, is selling $150 million of notes due in 2002 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are priced at 99.718 to yield 7.928 percent. The issue, which is noncallable, is rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service, AA- by S.& P, AA by Duff & Phelps and AA+ by Fitch.
